title: 112_hr1974
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Access to Congressionally Mandated Reports Act" and establishes a website for Congressionally mandated reports. The "Access to Congressionally Mandated Reports Act" requires the Public Printer to establish a website within a year for the public to access electronic copies of all congressionally mandated reports. The website must include citations to the statutes or conference reports requiring the reports, along with open-format electronic copies of the reports. The "Access to Congressionally Mandated Reports Act" mandates the establishment of a platform-independent website for public access to congressionally mandated reports. The website must allow easy retrieval of reports through various search criteria. The "Access to Congressionally Mandated Reports Act" requires a website for public access to mandated reports. The website must provide key details like the report number, statute, keywords, and full text search. Reports must be accessible within 30 days of submission, with a means for bulk download. The website required by the "Access to Congressionally Mandated Reports Act" must publish all congressionally mandated reports of Federal agencies, provide a searchable list of reports, and offer free access without any fees or registration. The website must also be regularly updated to fulfill the Act's purposes. Federal agencies are responsible for fulfilling the requirements of the "Access to Congressionally Mandated Reports Act." Federal agencies must publish congressionally mandated reports on their website in an open, machine-readable format without restrictions. They must also submit additional information to the Public Printer as required. Guidance on this process must be issued within eight months. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with the Public Printer, will issue guidance to agencies on implementing the Act within eight months of its enactment. SEC. 4. RELATIONSHIP TO REQUIREMENTS TO SUBMIT REPORTS TO CONGRESS. Federal agencies are required to publish unredacted reports on a designated website and notify Congress of their availability. Reports can only be altered or removed with congressional committee approval. SEC. 5. RELATIONSHIP TO FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT.

This Act does not require the disclosure of information exempt from public disclosure under section 552 of title 5, United States Code. If any information in a congressionally mandated report cannot be publicly released, the Federal agency must redact it from the report submitted for publication on the designated website and provide the reasons for each redaction.

SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines "congressionally mandated report" as a report required by Congress or a committee, and "Federal agency" as defined in title 40, excluding the Government Accountability Office.
